stems.text: A patient has been told that he has 6 months to live and there are no feasible treatments available. He insists, however, on a course of treatment that the doctor knows is unlikely to have any positive impacts on the patient’s longevity. How important to take into account are the following considerations for the doctor when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The right of the patient to be autonomously involved in his own treatment
questions.explanation: Patients with adequate mental capacity have the right to be involved in decisions regarding their treatment – this is a fundamental pillar of medical ethics

questions.text: That the medical team have more experience and expertise when it comes to choosing treatments
questions.explanation: While this may be true, the patient still has a role in deciding his treatment and should be listened to by the treating team

questions.text: Being positive and optimistic
questions.explanation: While it is important to maintain a positive outlook for the patient, this should not cloud the doctor’s understanding of the risks and limitations associated with ‘futile’ treatment

questions.text: That the patient might not have a clear understanding of the treatment and its pros and cons
questions.explanation: It is essential that the patient is adequately informed about a treatment before they commit to that course of action

questions.text: That the doctor does not believe that the pros of this treatment outweigh the cons
questions.explanation: While the doctor’s professional opinion should be valued, the patient’s views, thoughts and desires should also be considered

stems.text: A medical student, Petunia, has noticed her friend Joshua’s abrupt behaviour with patients. He doesn’t always ask for consent, often speaks in a condescending tone and can be quite rough as well. Most patients, however, don’t say anything about it. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Petunia when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The effect Joshua might be having on the reputation of the healthcare profession in the eyes of patients
questions.explanation: While it is important for medical students to uphold the reputation of the healthcare profession, there are other more pressing concerns including the impacts on patient welfare and trust

questions.text: Patients may not be comfortable sharing information with Joshua or other doctors
questions.explanation: This shows that Joshua’s actions are negatively impacting doctor-patient relationships and patient care

questions.text: That Joshua does not have malicious intents and often does so without realising
questions.explanation: Irrespective of the reason behind Joshua’s actions, patient care may be compromised, and action should be taken. The fact that Joshua does so without realising should, however, be an incentive to alert him to the effect he is having on patients

questions.text: That Joshua’s behaviour may make patients more reluctant to allow medical students to interview/exam them
questions.explanation: While this is definitely true, there are other more pressing concerns including the impacts on patient welfare and trust

questions.text: How Joshua will feel if Petunia raises the issue with the supervisor
questions.explanation: Patient welfare is the utmost priority here and regardless of how Joshua will react or feel, the issue must be dealt with

stems.text: Cindy is a junior doctor and is known for being forgetful; however, she is working on this. The previous day, a senior doctor had asked Cindy and Kathy, another medical student, to conduct a test on a patient. It was decided that Cindy would carry out the test but has forgotten to do so. The next day, the doctor asks for the results of the test. Kathy says nothing. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Cindy when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: Displaying honesty to the doctor
questions.explanation: Honesty and integrity are essential amongst healthcare professionals and admitting mistakes is pivotal

questions.text: That the doctor may get frustrated if he realises that she made another mistake
questions.explanation: To withhold information on this basis would be unprofessional – Cindy should own up to her mistake

questions.text: That she can blame Kathy for the issue
questions.explanation: Blaming Kathy, when it was agreed that Cindy would conduct the test, would be deceptive and highly unethical

questions.text: Taking action to reduce the likelihood of this happening again
questions.explanation: Everyone makes mistakes, the key is to reflect and learn from one’s errors in a professional manner to reduce the risk of them happening again

questions.text: That the doctor didn’t remind Cindy or Kathy to conduct the test
questions.explanation: It is not the doctor’s obligation to remind Cindy to conduct the test – she should have made note of this requirement herself

stems.text: Raman makes clinical skills notes which he sends to the medical cohort to help others in their preparation. Upon reviewing Raman’s notes, Matthew sees a picture of a patient from a consultation, this patient has not been deidentified and his name is visible. How important are the following considerations for Matthew when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That another student will likely report this
questions.explanation: It is incorrect to assume that another student would take action – Matthew should take a more proactive approach

questions.text: That Raman’s notes help out the whole cohort
questions.explanation: While this may be the case, patient information has been made available and, hence, action needs to be taken

questions.text: That the faculty should be alerted to this immediately
questions.explanation: While alerting the faculty to this will help resolve the situation, Raman should be first notified

questions.text: That Raman should be alerted to this immediately
questions.explanation: Raman may have unknowingly included this photo in his notes and should be alerted urgently so he can rectify this

questions.text: That the patient is very easy-going and probably wouldn’t mind
questions.explanation: Patient confidentiality must be upheld and, regardless of the patient’s nature, their private information should not be revealed to the medical cohort

stems.text: Michael has noticed that his friend, Robert, has changed recently. He has become withdrawn, antisocial and rude; he doesn’t even want to attend social events. He is studying medicine along with Michael and Michael believes that Robert might be having a hard time at home. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Michael when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That he should be there for Robert, if he needs someone to talk to
questions.explanation: As a friend, Michael should seek to keep an open channel of communication with Robert and provide support

questions.text: Robert will return to his normal self soon so he should not intervene
questions.explanation: While this may occur, Michael shouldn’t rely on this assumption. Potentially, Robert’s frame of mind could get worse instead

questions.text: That Robert may not want to talk
questions.explanation: While this should shape Michael’s approach to the situation, Michael should seek to open up dialogue regardless – especially being a close friend and given that Robert’s behaviour may be affecting others

questions.text: That Robert’s grades are being affected and it may impact his ability to be a doctor in the future
questions.explanation: Robert’s frame of mind may have reverberating impacts on his life and his career and, hence, Michael should seek to help him out in this scenario

questions.text: That there are support services for Robert to utilise and he may not be aware of these
questions.explanation: Michael should definitely outline the support services available for Robert to utilise to help him through this difficult time

stems.text: A medical student, Gloria, is working on a hospital ward. A patient, Bill, with severe back pain, is ready to be discharged. Gloria observes Bill taking a walking stick, from the hospital supplies without consulting anyone. Gloria knows that staff must provide permission for any of the supplies to be taken by a patient. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Gloria when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That Bill should not leave with the walking stick that has not been authorised
questions.explanation: It is against hospital policy to do so and this walking stick may be not suited for Bill or designated for someone else

questions.text: That none of the other stuff appears to have noticed
questions.explanation: Regardless of whether others have seen this action, it is essential for Gloria to intervene in this situation

questions.text: That Bill needs the stick to help him walk
questions.explanation: While this may be the case, it still needs to be properly authorised by hospital staff regardless

questions.text: That there are plenty of walking sticks in the supplies
questions.explanation: This is completely irrelevant. It is hospital policy to authorise the transferral of supplies and this must be done regardless

questions.text: That hospital staff should be notified of this
questions.explanation: It is essential that hospital policy is upheld and Gloria notifies the members of staff

stems.text: Dr Garthwaite has referred one of her patients to see a surgeon for an operation. While she knows that this surgeon is excellent at what he does, the patient appears uncomfortable. He states that he hasn’t heard good things about surgeon. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Dr Garthwaite when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That she is confident in the surgeon’s abilities
questions.explanation: The surgeon’s abilities will directly affect the outcome of the patient’s operation and if she is confident in him, she should tell this to the patient

questions.text: That there is no evidence of malpractice by the surgeon
questions.explanation: This is very important as the patient’s concerns are founded on rumours only and her opinion on this should be based on facts

questions.text: That she should explore the patient’s concerns further
questions.explanation: It is very appropriate to listen to the concerns of the patient and hear them out – to help reassure the patient

questions.text: Ask the patient if she should check whether another surgeon is free
questions.explanation: While this recognises the patient’s concerns, the doctor should seek to flesh out these concerns further and see whether there is a basis to them

questions.text: That the surgeon is a friend of Dr Garthwaite
questions.explanation: Personal acquaintances should not dictate Dr Garthwaite’s approach to the scenario – the priority is the patient’s outcome

stems.text: Kathryn is a GP, and she is undertaking a consultation with Mrs Green, a 42 year-old woman. Mrs Green has had 2 children in the past 3 years and she is in the early stages of her 3rd. Kathryn has previously told Mrs Green that, after 35, the risk of genetic abnormalities of the child and potentially life-threatening birth complications increases exponentially. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Kathryn when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That if she does not inform Mrs Green again about these risks, Mrs Green may become pregnant again and risk birth complications/genetic abnormalities
questions.explanation: Without imparting judgement, it is very important for the doctor to explain the risks and potential health complications to the patient

questions.text: That the information about these risks is provided respectfully
questions.explanation: Advice should always be delivered in a respectful and caring way so as not to upset Mrs the patient

questions.text: That Mrs Green is given all the information she needs to make informed decisions in the future
questions.explanation: Kathryn cannot enforce any behaviour/courses of action to be carried out by the patient, she can only provide advice and help Mrs Green make a decision

questions.text: That Mrs Green should be told not to have another child due to the risks associated
questions.explanation: Kathryn cannot enforce any behaviour/courses of action to be carried out by the patient, she can only provide advice and help Mrs Green make a decision

questions.text: That Mrs Green should be told to abort her child due to the risks associated
questions.explanation: Kathryn cannot enforce any behaviour/courses of action to be carried out by the patient, she can only provide advice and help Mrs Green make a decision

stems.text: During a GP placement, Julia observes Lawrence, another medical student, taking a video on his mobile phone. While the university/clinic policy allows this for educational purposes, anything related to patient information cannot be discussed. Patient information and the patient’s name has been discussed during the consult. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Julia when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That importance of following policy
questions.explanation: Policy is in place to protect all those involved and should always be adhered to

questions.text: That she does not know whether Lawrence has gotten permission to record
questions.explanation: Lawrence may or may not have been given permission to record the consult – either way, Julia shouldn't make an assumption until she has found out the facts

questions.text: Maintaining the confidentiality of patient information
questions.explanation: All patients have the fundamental right to privacy and all medical practitioners must strive to maintain this confidentiality – recording without permission may be a breach of this

questions.text: That the patient’s name and information has been mentioned
questions.explanation: Recording this is strictly against the policy and thus this is an essential consideration

questions.text: Recording the interaction may help Lawrence’s learning
questions.explanation: Patient welfare and privacy must come before this notion; hence, relatively, the benefit to Lawrence’s learning has no bearing whatsoever

stems.text: Jim and Dylan are currently junior doctors working together ad have been good friends since medical school. Recently, Jim has noticed Dylan’s behaviour change. He appears frustrated and confused and has been making more errors recently. Dylan tells Jim that he has been having issues with his relationship and is striggling at the moment. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Jim when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That other staff may have more of a workload due to Dylan’s behaviour and errors
questions.explanation: While the workload of staff is an important consideration, it is more important to consider the direct effects on Chris' own patients

questions.text: That Dylan has been making mistakes when interacting with patients
questions.explanation: While mistakes are part of the process, they should be learned from. Repeated mistakes may be putting patient welfare at risk

questions.text: That Dylan has been abrupt with patients
questions.explanation: Being irritable or abrupt with patients is unacceptable, this can impact patient trust and is not professional

questions.text: That Dylan has been rude with other staff
questions.explanation: This is unprofessional, may erode working relationships in the hospital and may ultimately jeopardise patient care

questions.text: That Dylan might need his space to deal with the situation and doesn’t want to talk about it
questions.explanation: While this may be true, the welfare and impacts of his behaviour on patient and staff are the primary concern here and his behaviour should be addressed regardless
